passages.text: Reiterate Rating: UNDERPERFORM | PO: 465.00 HKD | Price: 460.40 HKD

We lift our 2025/26/27E EPS \(12.6\% /1.6\% /0.4\%\) post its 1H25 earnings beat (see our first- take note), and maintain our Underperform rating and PO of HK\$465. 1H25 beat leads to our 2025 estimate upgrade, but we have made only minimal changes to our 2026/27E EPS, as we believe the beat could be more attributable to delivery subsidies from online platforms (which is one- off in nature). Mixue's earnings call also did not offer detailed breakdown on its \(13\%\) growth of sales per weighted store in 1H25, leaving more questions than answers. We continue to view Mixue as China's largest and best freshly- made tea drinks company, but we maintain our U/P rating due to less compelling valuation ( \(>20x\) 2026E P/E for below- trend EPS growth), tough comps in 2026, growing pains related to Southeast Asia (SEA) and uncertainties of social security issues of its franchisees.

1) China. Mixue attributes its topline strength to store expansion, delivery subsidies and operational enhancement. Lucky Cup (its coffee brand) enjoys solid momentum in terms of expansion and sales per store. Mixue also sees ample room for expansion in coming years. 2) Delivery subsidies in China. Mixue expects subsidies to abate gradually, and already observes slowing delivery growth in July vs. June. Meanwhile, it has not offered additional color on delivery sales contribution in 1H25 (2024: c.25%). 3) Overseas. Mixue trimmed its network in SEA (mainly Indonesia and Vietnam) in 1H25. Sales/store improved, partly on easy comps and partly on self-help. Mixue has taken various measures in store optimization, supply chains, organizations and branding to improve its SEA business. Meanwhile, it expanded to Central Asia (Kazakhstan) in 1H25 and plans to further expand to the US, Mexico and Brazil in the near future. It will start with equity stores in new regions first, and later shift to franchised stores. 4) Margins. While Mixue maintains its long-term GPM target of 30%, its GPM reached 31.6% in 1H25 (only ~30bp YoY) and the company sees a relatively steady trend in the near term. It also expects SG&A/sales to be largely stable, as sales leverage can be offset by investment in overseas expansion.

Founded by Mr.Zhang Hongchao in Zhengzhou, China in 1997, Mixue is the No.1 freshly- made tea drinks company in China and Southeast Asia (as of 2023), with exposure to freshly- made coffee. The company mainly provides value- for- money products to consumers, including freshly- made fruit drinks, tea drinks, ice cream and coffee. Through a franchise model, the company operated 46.5k stores at end- 24. The company listed in HKEX on March 3, 2025.

We have an Underperform rating on Mixue. While we regard Mixue as China's largest and best freshly- made tea drinks company, we believe its valuation has run ahead of its fundamentals, after a huge rally since its IPO. In our view, the market has not paid due attention to its near- term margin pressure. Moreover, its setbacks with overseas and coffee businesses could also cap its long- term upside.
Price to Book Value 6.6x

We lift our 2025/26E EPS by \(12.6\% /1.6\%\) and largely maintain our 2027E EPS. We maintain our PO of HK\$465. Our PO is based on a 50/50 blend of P/E and DCF. Our P/E based value is HK\$471, based on 25x 2026 P/E. Our target multiple is \(10\%\) lower than the average of HK listed new consumption peers, and also implies 1.2x PEG. Our DCF based valuation is HK\$458, applying \(12\%\) WACC (3% risk- free rate and 9% market risk premium), 1.0x beta, and 3.5% terminal growth. We also assume HKSCNY FX rate at 0.92.

Our PO of HK\$465 is based on a 50/50 blend of P/E and DCF. Our P/E based value is HK\$471, based on 25x 2026 P/E. Our target multiple is \(10\%\) lower than the average of HK listed new consumption peers, and also implies \(1.2x\) PEG. Our DCF based valuation is HK\$458, applying \(12\%\) WACC (3% risk- free rate and 9% market risk premium), 1.0x beta, and \(3.5\%\) terminal growth. We also assume HK\\(CNY FX rate at 0.92.
Downside risks are: Risks related to franchisees, food safety and hygiene control, competition, rising raw material cost, execution risks of overseas expansion, epidemic risk, key personnel risk.
Upside risks are: Rising consumer demand, successful overseas expansion, raw material cost downcycle.
